Option C is acetylcholine. Acetylcholine is a neurotransmitter. When released from its receptor sites, it quickly moves into the cell interior via a rapid channel called the K+ ion channel. This allows acetylcholine to enter the synaptic clefts and then cross over to the other end of the neuron. Once inside, it binds to G proteins, which in turn activate target genes. That means acetylcholine does act as an intracellular messenger, so C is not the exception we're looking for.

Lastly, option D is inositol 1,4,5-triphosphate. I'm trying to remember where this comes from. I recall that inositol triphosphate (IP3) is a precursor to inositol diphospholipids (IDP), which are used in the translocase process. The translocase moves IP3 into the ER, and once there, it becomes IDP, which then moves into the Golgi apparatus to become PEP. These are all part of the signaling cascade in cells, especially in the context of hormone receptors and neurotransmitters. So D is also functioning as an intracellular messenger.

Putting it all together, A, B, C, and D are all known as intracellular messengers. Therefore, the one that doesn't serve as such a messenger is A, calcium ions.
</think>
The correct answer is A
